<p>Since <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.45</mn><mo>&lt;</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1.96</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-2.45 &lt; -1.96</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord">2.45</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord">1.96</span></span></span></span></span>, we reject <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. There is sufficient evidence to claim the proportion of support is not 50%.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="one-tailed-and-two-tailed-tests">30. One-Tailed and Two-Tailed Tests</h2>
<p>The type of hypothesis test (one-tailed or two-tailed) depends on the alternative hypothesis.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>One-Tailed Test:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> The alternative hypothesis specifies a direction of difference (e.g., greater than or less than). The rejection region is entirely in one tail of the sampling distribution.</p>

</li>
<li>
<p><strong>P-value:</strong> The P-value is twice the area in one tail (the tail corresponding to the calculated test statistic).</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Choosing the Test:</strong> The choice of one-tailed or two-tailed test must be made <em>before</em> data collection and analysis, based on the research question or the specific claim being investigated.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="paired-t-test">31. Paired t-Test</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A statistical test used to compare the means of two related groups or measurements. It is appropriate when each observation in one group is paired with an observation in the other group.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Common Applications:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>“Before-and-after” studies (e.g., weight before and after a diet).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Comparing two different treatments applied to the same subjects.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Comparing two methods when measurements are taken on the same items.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Key Idea:</strong> Instead of analyzing the two groups separately, we calculate the <em>difference</em> between the paired observations and then perform a one-sample t-test on these differences.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Hypotheses:</strong> Let <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.84444em; </li>
<li>

</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Assumptions:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The paired differences are independent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The population of differences is approximately normally distributed (or <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> is large enough for CLT).</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>

<h2 id="simple-linear-regression">32. Simple Linear Regression</h2>
<p>Simple linear regression is a statistical method that allows us to summarize and study relationships between two continuous variables: a dependent variable (response) and an independent variable (predictor).</p>
<h3 id="regression-equation-least-squares-regression-line">32.1. Regression Equation (Least Squares Regression Line)</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> The equation of the straight line that best describes the linear relationship between two variables. It is determined by minimizing the sum of the squared vertical distances from the data points to the line (the “least squares” criterion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Formula for the Estimated Regression Line:</strong></p>

<p>Where:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>: The predicted value of the dependent (response) variable.</p>

<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>: The independent (predictor) variable.</p>

<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b_0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.84444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>: The Y-intercept of the regression line. </li>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.84444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>: The slope of the regression line. </li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Example:</strong> Predicting a student’s final exam score (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span></span></span></span>) based on the number of hours they studied (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>).<br>
If the regression equation is <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y} = 50 + 5X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A student who studies 0 hours is predicted to score 50.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For every additional hour studied, the predicted score increases by 5 points.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>

<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b_0 = 75 - 5(5) = 75 - 25 = 50</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.84444em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; <li>

<h3 id="correlation-r">32.3. <ul>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-1 \le r \le 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.78041em; vertical-align: -0.13597em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≤</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.77194em; vertical-align: -0.13597em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≤</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">r=-1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> indicates a perfect negative linear relationship.</p>

<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">r=0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span> indicates no linear relationship.</p>
</li>

</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Interpretation:</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ranges from 0 to 1.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2 = 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2 = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; </li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Example (Continued):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>From the previous example, <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">r=1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2 = r^2 = 1^2 = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; </li>
<li>
<p>This means that 100% of the variation in exam scores can be explained by the number of hours studied. This is because the example data points fall perfectly on a straight line. In real-world data, <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.814108em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is typically between 0 and 1, indicating some but not all variation is explained.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>

<h3 id="prediction">32.5. Prediction</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> Using the established regression equation to estimate the value of the dependent variable (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) for a given new value of the independent variable (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Process:</strong> Simply substitute the new <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> value into the estimated regression equation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Caution (Extrapolation):</strong> Avoid making predictions for <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> values outside the range of the observed data used to build the model. This is called extrapolation and can lead to unreliable predictions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Example (Continued):</strong> Predict the exam score for a student who studies 7 hours.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Regression equation: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y} = 50 + 5X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X=7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span></span></span></span></span>: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>35</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>85</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y} = 50 + 5(7) = 50 + 35 = 85</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">85</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A student who studies 7 hours is predicted to score 85.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="residual-analysis">32.6. Residual Analysis</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A residual is the difference between an observed value of the dependent variable (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>Y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Y_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; </li>
<li>
<p><strong>Purpose of Analysis:</strong> Residual analysis is crucial for checking the assumptions of linear regression and assessing the appropriateness of the model. Plotting residuals against predicted values, independent variables, or observation order can reveal patterns that indicate violations of assumptions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Assumptions of Linear Regression (checked using residuals):</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Linearity:</strong> The relationship between <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span></span></span></span> is linear. (Residuals should show no discernible pattern when plotted against <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Independence of Errors:</strong> Residuals are independent of each other. (No pattern in residuals plotted against time or order).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Homoscedasticity (Constant Variance):</strong> The variance of the residuals is constant across all levels of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>. (The spread of residuals around 0 should be roughly consistent across the range of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>Y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{Y}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.94677em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.94677em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.25233em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.25em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Normality of Errors:</strong> The residuals are normally distributed. (Can be checked with a histogram of residuals or a Q-Q plot).</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>

<td align="left"><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 + 5(8) = 90</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">90</span></span></span></span></span></td>
<td align="left"><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 - 90 = 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.72777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord">90</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">90</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table><p>In this perfectly linear example, all residuals are 0. In real-world scenarios, residuals would be non-zero, and their pattern (or lack thereof) would be analyzed. For instance, a “fanning out” pattern in a residual plot would suggest heteroscedasticity (non-constant variance).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="randomstochastic-processes">33. Random/Stochastic Processes</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A random process (also known as a stochastic process) is a collection of random variables indexed by time or space. Unlike a single random variable that describes a single uncertain outcome, a random process describes the evolution of a random phenomenon over time or space.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Key Idea:</strong> A random process produces a sequence of random values. Each value in the sequence is a random variable, and the sequence itself represents a possible “path” or “realization” of the process.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Notation:</strong> A random process is often denoted as <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{X(t), t \in T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span></span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{X_t, t \in T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.87777em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.280556em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.07847em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">t</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span></span></span></span></span></span>, where <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.61508em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span> is the index (time, usually).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Random Variable vs. Random Process:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A <strong>random variable</strong> is a single outcome of an experiment (e.g., the temperature at 10 AM today).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A <strong>random process</strong> is a collection of such random variables, describing how that outcome <em>changes over time</em> (e.g., the temperature measured every hour throughout the day, or the stock price minute by minute).</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Examples:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Stock prices over time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Number of customers arriving at a store over time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Temperature readings at different locations on a map.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The path of a diffusing particle.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="poisson-process">33.1. Poisson Process</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A counting process that models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time or space, where these events happen independently and at a constant average rate. It’s often used to model rare events.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Characteristics/Assumptions:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Stationarity:</strong> The rate of events (<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span></span></span>) is constant over time. The number of events in any interval depends only on the length of the interval, not on its starting point.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Independent Increments:</strong> The number of events in non-overlapping intervals are independent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Ordinary (or Non-simultaneous Events):</strong> It is impossible for two or more events to occur at precisely the same instant.</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Parameter:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span></span></span>: The average rate of events per unit time (or space). It’s also known as the intensity or rate parameter.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Key Components:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N(t)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≥</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span></span> is the Poisson process.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Formulas:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Probability of</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> <strong>events in an interval of length</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.61508em; <li>
<p><strong>Time between events (Inter-arrival times):</strong> The time between consecutive events in a Poisson process follows an Exponential distribution with rate <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>λ</mi><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>λ</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>for&nbsp;</mtext><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x} \quad \text{for } x \ge 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.03508em; vertical-align: -0.13597em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.899108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The expected time between events is <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E[X] = 1/\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Example:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Customers arrive at a bank at an average rate of 10 customers per hour. <h3 id="random-walk">33.2. Random Walk</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A mathematical formalization of a path that consists of a sequence of random steps on some mathematical space (e.g., integers, a grid). Each step is chosen randomly.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Key Idea:</strong> The position at any given time depends on the previous position plus a random “step.”</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Types:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Simple Random Walk:</strong> At each step, movement is only allowed to adjacent positions with equal probability.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>One-dimensional Random Walk:</strong> Movement along a line (integers).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Multi-dimensional Random Walk:</strong> Movement on a grid or in higher dimensions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Formulas (for a simple symmetric 1D random walk):</strong></p>
<ul>

<h3 id="markov-chains">33.3. Markov Chains</h3>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A stochastic process that describes a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Key Idea:</strong> “The future is independent of the past, given the present.” This is known as the <strong>Markov Property</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Components:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>State:</strong> A possible condition or configuration of the system being modeled. For a Markov chain, the system is always in one of a finite or countably infinite number of states.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Transitions:</strong> Movement from one state to another.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Transition Probabilities:</strong> The probabilities of moving from one state to another. These are usually represented in a <strong>transition matrix</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Markov Property:</strong> The assumption that the future state of a system depends only on its current state, and not on any previous states. Formally:</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>j</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>i</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>…</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>j</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P(X_{t+1}=j | X_t=i, X_{t-1}=i_{t-1}, \dots, X_0=i_0) = P(X_{t+1}=j | X_t=i)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; <li>
<p><strong>Stationary Distribution (Steady-State Distribution):</strong> For some Markov chains (specifically, irreducible and aperiodic Markov chains), after a very long time, the probability of being in any given state becomes constant, regardless of the initial state. This limiting probability distribution is called the stationary distribution, denoted by <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>π</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>…</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>π</mi><mi>N</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pi = (\pi_1, \pi_2, \dots, \pi_N)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; <ul>
<li>
<p>It satisfies the equation: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pi = \pi P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">π</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">π</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>And the sum of probabilities must be 1: <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></msubsup><msub><mi>π</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sum_{i=1}^{N} \pi_i = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.28094em; </li>
<li>
<p>This means that if the system starts in the stationary distribution, it will remain in that distribution for all subsequent steps.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Expected Value (in the context of Markov Chains):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>While individual states don’t usually have numerical “values” that are averaged directly like a random variable, we can talk about the expected number of steps to reach a certain state (hitting time) or the expected number of times a state is visited in a certain period.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>More commonly, “expected value” refers to the expected state of the system if states are mapped to numerical values, or the expected long-run average of some function of the state, calculated using the stationary distribution.</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Example (Weather Model Continued):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Suppose the weather in a city can be in one of three states: Sunny (S), Cloudy ©, or Rainy ®. The weather tomorrow depends only on the weather today.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Transition Probabilities:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If Sunny today: 0.8 chance Sunny tomorrow, 0.1 Cloudy, 0.1 Rainy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If Cloudy today: 0.2 chance Sunny tomorrow, 0.6 Cloudy, 0.2 Rainy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If Rainy today: 0.2 chance Sunny tomorrow, 0.3 Cloudy, 0.5 Rainy.</p>
</li>
</ul>
